facts: The speed of light in vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 meters per second.
Water is the only substance on Earth that naturally occurs in three states: solid, liquid, and gas.
The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons.
DNA was first isolated by Friedrich Miescher in 1869.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun, reaching temperatures of about 5,700°C.
A single bolt of lightning contains enough energy to toast 100,000 slices of bread.
Oxygen was discovered independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Joseph Priestley in the 1770s.
The Milky Way galaxy contains an estimated 100-400 billion stars.
Human DNA is 99.9% identical between any two individuals.
The universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old.
Electrons move through the wire at a speed of a few centimeters per second.
A teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about 6 billion tons.
The speed of sound varies depending on the medium it travels through.
Photosynthesis converts carbon dioxide and water into glucose using light energy.
The periodic table was created by Dmitri Mendeleev in 1869.
Quantum entanglement allows particles to be instantly connected across vast distances.
The human genome contains approximately 3 billion base pairs.
Black holes can slow down time due to their extreme gravitational fields.
Chlorophyll makes plants green by absorbing red and blue light.
Sound cannot travel through a vacuum because there are no particles to vibrate.
The largest volcano in our solar system is Olympus Mons on Mars.
Penicillin was discovered accidentally by Alexander Fleming in 1928.
The coldest temperature ever recorded on Earth was -89.2°C in Antarctica.
Diamonds are formed under extreme pressure and temperature deep within Earth.
The human eye can distinguish about 10 million different colors.
Bacteria make up approximately 90% of the cells in the human body.
The aurora borealis is caused by solar particles colliding with Earth's atmosphere.
A single strand of spider silk is stronger than steel of the same thickness.
The fastest computer processor can perform trillions of calculations per second.
Helium was first discovered on the Sun before being found on Earth.
The human heart beats approximately 100,000 times per day.
Graphene is the strongest material ever tested, 200 times stronger than steel.
The Earth's magnetic field is generated by its liquid iron core.
A single human brain generates more electrical impulses in a day than all telephones in the world combined.
The International Space Station travels at a speed of about 28,000 km/h.
Vaccines work by training the immune system to recognize and fight pathogens.
The smallest bone in the human body is the stapes in the middle ear.
Nuclear fusion in the Sun converts 600 million tons of hydrogen into helium every second.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest living structure on Earth.
Antibiotics are ineffective against viral infections.
The Hubble Space Telescope has observed galaxies up to 13.4 billion light-years away.
Water expands when it freezes, which is why ice floats.
The human body contains enough carbon to make 900 pencils.
Mitochondria are the powerhouses of cells, generating ATP for energy.
The planet Venus has a day longer than its year.
Gravity is the weakest of the four fundamental forces of nature.
The first synthetic element was Technetium, created in 1937.
Electromagnetic waves include radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
The human skeleton is composed of 206 bones in adulthood.
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.
The Doppler effect explains why a siren's pitch changes as it moves past you.
RNA can act as both genetic material and as enzymes called ribozymes.
The Hubble constant measures the rate of expansion of the universe.
Stem cells have the potential to develop into many different cell types.
The Earth rotates at a speed of about 1,670 km/h at the equator.
Superconductors conduct electricity without resistance at very low temperatures.
The chemical formula for table salt is NaCl (sodium chloride).
A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, about 9.46 trillion kilometers.
The human stomach can hold approximately 1.5 liters of material.
CRISPR technology allows precise editing of DNA sequences.
The greenhouse effect is essential for life but is enhanced by human activities.
Absolute zero is the lowest possible temperature at -273.15°C or 0 Kelvin.
The ozone layer protects Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation.
Enzymes are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions.
Mars has the largest dust storms in the solar system.
The human body contains about 60% water.
Antimatter particles have the opposite charge of their matter counterparts.
The Pythagorean theorem relates the sides of right-angled triangles.
Coral reefs support about 25% of all marine species.
The theory of relativity was developed by Albert Einstein.
Chromosomes carry genetic information in the form of genes.
The moon is gradually moving away from Earth at about 3.8 cm per year.
Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe's mass-energy content.
The strongest muscle in the human body relative to its size is the masseter (jaw muscle).
Newton's laws of motion describe the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration.
Red blood cells carry oxygen throughout the body using hemoglobin.
The coldest place in the universe is the Boomerang Nebula at -272°C.
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.
The human nose can detect over 1 trillion different scents.
Saturn's rings are made primarily of ice particles.
Metamorphosis is the process by which some animals drastically change form.

Bioluminescence is the production of light by living organisms.

The cerebral cortex is responsible for higher-level thinking in humans.

Natural selection is the mechanism driving evolution.
The human brain uses about 20% of the body's energy despite being only 2% of its mass.
Supernova explosions create and distribute heavy elements throughout the universe.
Ribosomes are cellular structures that synthesize proteins.

Genetic mutations are changes in DNA sequences.
The conservation of momentum is a fundamental principle in physics.

Quarks are fundamental particles that make up protons and neutrons.

Hormones are chemical messengers in the endocrine system.
The Fermi paradox questions why we haven't detected extraterrestrial civilizations.
Photons are particles of light with no mass.

The human immune system has both innate and adaptive components.
Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars that emit beams of radiation.

The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed.
